pros: The lower level staff were the only positive about working for NWAC, people who genuinely cared about their work and impact on community.
cons: The entire leadership, especially the CEO, is incredibly toxic and harmful. It was probably one of the most unhealthiest workplace environments I've ever been in, and working there profoundly affected my mental health. The CEO is abusive, harrassed staff at all hours of the night, and would constantly treat everything as "a fire" that needed to be put out. The salary was very low, way below market, and the benefits and vacation time are not competitive. The CEO would call employees ungrateful for asking for more vacation time (low-level staff only get 2 weeks) and berate staff who complained about working too much saying she worked 80 hours a week without complaint. Employees who are fired or let go are offered a higher severance if they sign an NDA - this is what keeps past employees from reporting the CEO and NWAC to the labour board. Lastly, when I was employed the vast majority of management and leadership were men and non-Indigenous women in an organization dedicated to advancing the rights of Indigenous women. How does that work? If you value your mental health and well being, do not work here.

pros: There are lots of great people at the ground level. And the pay and benefits can be decent.
cons:
There’s so much turnover and change it’s unbelievable. People change job titled every two months, and are shuffled from project to project like sheep.

Management are trying hard to change the org but are incompetent and have little respect for base level employees. Employees don’t get the most basic information to do their jobs. Salaries are grossly unequal, and sometimes ground level employees are the same or more as their managers.

Financial processes have improved but are so clumsy, and approvals take much too long.

The disorganization is embarrassing, even for important milestone events.

Financial decisions are suspect, and money gets arbitrarily taken from project budgets leaving little left to do the actual work.

Project timelines get shortened to a level where the only reasonable action is to turn in a substandard product.

Yes there’s a fancy new building but I wouldn’t recommend anyone join this organization.

pros: I have worked for many not for profit organizations and I must say that working at NWAC is a real pleasure. My suggestions are listened to and I am treated with respect. The organization genuinely believes in their mission and I am so happy to be a part of making the lives of Indigenous women better. The leadership at NWAC is visionary while at the same time, down to earth. We can actually see our work in action. The CEO is smart and experienced. Her senior management team is committed to the organization and that trickles right through the work force. The benefits are excellent and the morale is high. I enjoy this job and look forward to being here a long time!
cons: Because of financial restraints, the organization cannot always do everything it wants to but that is no fault of NWAC's. That said, they are able to prioritize well. Also, with the impact of COVID, it is harder to work like a team but NWAC management makes an extra effort to meet on-line often to make sure we are all connected.

pros: Because the level of abuse and harassment from the CEO is so high, you might get a free pizza lunch every once in a while as an attempt to make you forget everything you've been through.
cons:
A typical day at work....
Start your commute to the downtown office location. Feel your blood pressure and anxiety heighten the closer you get. 
Open your work email on your phone and discover the 13 emails sent to you overnight at 2 or 3 AM. Sift through the panicky-emails sent to you from the ED's admin assistant - who is verging on a complete burn-out.
Stand at the door of your office for a while because your door code doesn't work - someone was canned yesterday and the door codes were changed-AGAIN.
Sit at your desk and listen to staff member after staff member, complain and cry of how they are treated. Try to give them advice, direct them to HR.
Now its time to address the 30+ condescending and belittling emails sent to you while you were talking to staff.
Assign duties to your staff - overload them, convince them that this is normal and/or appropriate because the CEO doesn't care what your department's actual capacity is. She wants MORE MONEY and FAME at whatever and whoever's cost.
So we work hard, respond to unreasonable and outlandish requests from the CEO's office. Amidst the incredible pressure, we get through our tasks each day, actually do a damn good job, but there is no time for positive reinforcement from the CEO because she is already sending you nasty emails about the next thing you should be working on (that you didn't even know about).
At this point in the day, you remember that you haven't eaten yet and you should probably go to the washroom. But then you've been summoned to the monsters den where you watch her pick through today's array of snacks delivered by staff and paid by tax-payers (she works so hard micro-managing all day and night so therefore has no time to prepare and bring her own lunch) - watching her gnaw on candy as she rips you a new one has ruined sour jujubes for me.
After a good 9 hours of work AKA "place of many anxiety attacks", go home and think about what craziness is in store for you tomorrow. who will be fired today? Will the police show up to the office today? Who is scheduled for the next office melt-down? Will this awful feeling ever go away when I see a jujube? I wonder if _____(insert name of the week) will ever come back from their sick leave?

Words can't describe the feeling of working for this organization with the current CEO in charge. The CEO manages people using intimidation, straight up harassment and ultimatums.  She convinces herself that her crazy, spur of the moment ideas are appropriate. People are completely replaceable, "Accountants and Policy people are a dime a dozen". She has successfully brainwashed the on-salary in-house NWAC lawyer to not look after the best interests of the organization as a whole but rather protect her as an individual as she is NWAC - the "Queen of NWAC".
It is truly sad that an organization that advocates for Indigenous women is caught treating the very people they represent worse than any other agency or company I know. Horrible pay, mediocre benefits, terrible - shared working conditions, high stress, etc.

Do not be fooled, you WILL be fired or pushed out of your job. If you have ethics, are empathetic or are any decent type of individual, you will not last long at this organization with the current management.

It shocks me that a Board of Directors would allow someone to do this to such an important organization. They all know what is happening at this place google NWAC and CBC.

review_title: NWAC could be great, but the ED/"CEO" needs to be dealt with
pros: NWAC was a dream job when I first started - I was working on policy files I loved, getting experience with senior level work in an entry-level position, the relationships with my co-workers were wonderful. I worked at NWAC for a year and a half but it was really only the first six months that I felt safe and valued as an employee.
cons:
NWAC is a great organization and is capable of doing great work, but not with the current leadership.  They have compromised on NWAC's values in their operation of the organization and have undermined the credibility of NWAC's advocacy.  I wish I could provide more context for this claim, but I truly have never met anyone more manipulative, calculated, or deceitful.  While many of these reviews mention the ED/"CEO", we are not just spiteful former employees.  Many were forced out for challenging the ED/"CEO" and others left to care for their mental health.  We followed all internal conflict resolution processes, we wrote a letter to the board of directors with our concerns, some spoke to the press - but NWAC just kept hitting a new bottom.  

- Staff have no job security in their contracts and are often fired without notice and without adequate reason. These firings are frequently defended by management and blamed on unstable project funding from the government (a way they can also strategically advocate for more core organizational funding).  Staff are now made to sign non-disclosure agreements before being given their contracts which I think is for efficiency more than anything else. 

- Constant gaslighting - Staff are made to feel like they are asking for too much. Whether it be an adequate salary (to match the salaries of our project budgets), an adequate workspace with HR accommodations, or approval for overtime to meet the demands of the workload, we were always told there was never funding.  We were told these things are part of non-profit work, which to a degree, was acceptable.  But as time went on, it became increasingly obvious that the ED/”CEO” just operates NWAC in a state of chaos as a way to controlling staff.  When you are constantly putting out small fires, its easy to miss the larger shifts taking place.  

- Intentionally weak directorship  -  Aside from a few women who are exceptions to the rule, the ED/"CEO" has strategically selected people not suited to director and senior management positions.  Most lack the experience to lead their units and senior-level work frequently falls to lower-level staff, but without the recognition or compensation.  For these reasons, many staff leave NWAC without a reference from a supervisor or director.  There are few opportunities for mentorship, especially given the incredibly high turnover rate.
 
- Lack of Indigenous staff - I write this as a non-Indigenous former employee but this is incredibly important.  NWAC is a colonized space, which is likely why it has struggled to attract and retain Indigenous staff.  When the lack of Indigenous women in leadership positions was brought to her attention, the ED/"CEO" would constantly say that no qualified Indigenous women were applying – which to her meant no women with law degrees or PhDs were applying.  Leadership does not value lived experience or traditional knowledge, with the exception of several Elder Advisor roles.  Despite advocating for solutions to the systemic reasons why Indigenous women are under-represented in post-secondary education, NWAC continues to favour non-Indigenous folks with graduate degrees and experience in government.  Despite advocating for the economic empowerment of Indigenous women, NWAC has given the highest-paying senior positions (100k+) to white men while the majority of staff are making under 40k.
